messageBody:
So said cdtmp on 2002-10-06

>I'd appreciate some pointers (even pointers to the manual since I
>can't find this in there).
>
>I have an situation where the effect of a method is to send (or not to
>send) a message through either a serial port, socket or similar.
>
>The behavior is controlled by a (number of) well defined state
>diagrams. Summarizing a huge specification, messages are sent through
>the ports based on transitions and the exisiting state of hierachical
>state diagrams. The situation seems ideal for unit testing since the
>whole environment is complex and unit testing would ensure that the
>messages sent, based on the state transitions are correct after
>modifications and we could automatically test a huge number of cases.
> It's not actually _what_ is sent, since that can be tested, but it's
>that the correct sequence of messages was requested to be sent (based,
>in this case, on string identifiers).
>
>My problem is that the state of the object after the call is the same
>as before the call, or at least the sending of the message is not, and
>cannot easily be indicated in the state of the object without changing
>the runtime behavior of the object.
>
>I hope all this makes sense. I'd appreciate any suggestions. My only
>thought for checking this is something like a log file, or Log4J
>logger. After the test I could check the logger and make sure that it
>contains _exactly_ what I would expect - but this seems somewhat
complex.

First, let me answer the direct question. As a first suggestion, if
you're interested in verifying the sequence of events, then you
probably need a way to log the events. I suggest logging them in memory
by using an event/listener design. In the simplest case, use a
collecting parameter in the constructor of the object you want to
observe, then have that object signal events to the collector as things
happen. At the end of the test, verify that the collector has collected
the expected events in the expected order. If you prefer not to change
the object under test, then you can certainly create a decorator of the
object under test and separate the event-firing into that decorator.
(You may want to do that anyway.)

To test:

class MessageSender {
sendMessage(message) { ... }
...
}

You write:

class MessageSpy extends MessageSender {
Collection messages;

sendMessage(message) {
messages.add(message);
super.sendMessage(message);
}
}

Now you can create a MessageSpy in your tests and test that the
messages are sent as expected.

Now the next part of the message: if you're testing that a sequence of
messages is correct, that points to testing something bigger than you'd
like to test. Although sometimes you do actually want to test that a
sequence of messages is correct, often what you really want to test is
that in situation X under conditions Y, when Z happens, the object
sends message M. It is usually better to test based on observable
behavior than to test based on knowledge of the order in which code
executes. The latter is less resistant to change.

Just food for thought; not a critique of what you're doing. :)
